posts.name:
Chetan Ahuja
Chetan Ahuja
posts.content:
The definition of top 1% founder is different today, don‚Äôt get sucked in to ‚Äúbuilding great product is enough‚Äù

I speak to 100s of founders every year, and most believe that building a great product is enough.

But here‚Äôs the truth: the top-performing founders do much more.

Follow these essentials to set you apart:

- Talk to your users every week
- Solve real problems, not just build features
- Focus on what works, not what's trending
- Build with intention, not FOMO
- Take care of your mental health
- Have a small team that believes in your vision
- Stay close to your core product
- Measure impact, not just metrics

I see founders constantly chasing the next big thing. New technologies, bigger teams, faster growth.

But here's what I've learned helping founders build companies; the fundamentals haven't changed:
‚Üí Users who love your product
‚Üí a team that believes in the mission,
‚Üí and problems worth solving

these are still what separate great companies from good ones.

It's not about doing everything.
It's about doing the right things well.

If you've got these basics right, you're already building something special.

What keeps you focused on what matters?

comments.commentText: We mailed you but it's showing not delivered
Master Vishal Hi, can u please resend on chetan@debtworks.co.in

Having a great idea is not enough, we have to execute that idea. Also we should have bias for action. By taking action we may fail but the holy grail of the entrepreneur is to fail early and fail often so that you will have time and energy to transform your failures into lessons and thus success.
Also great founders are ahead of their times. Yes, they are great visionaries but their visions are in sync with real world. Every product or idea addresses a pain, to be precise pain of their customer.
Also growth has to be sustainable. An individual is not enough to achieve world class success. We need team of cofounders with shared mission and vision. When one of cofounder is low on energy then team of others should come forward and pull him up. The mental health issues need to be addressed from time to time.

posts.name:
Tate Stone
Tate Stone
posts.content:
What is an ‚Äúopportunity‚Äù?

Like literally, in your CRM what does an opportunity mean?

Is the definition of an opportunity consistent across the team?

When do they get created?

How are they qualified?

These seem like simple questions but if every rep on your team has different answers to them, your reporting and forecasting will forever be a nightmare.

You have to have standard, common language and processes for even simple things like this.

comments.commentText: Standardized sales qualifications is the hallmark of a great sales team and a good product/ service market fit. You should know their BANT and the leads business goals, challenges, plans. There should be a demonstration of some sort as well either before or right after qualification (depending on the business). All sales business processes should be standardized and digitized into your sales pipeline.

posts.name:
Priya Subramanian
Priya Subramanian
posts.content:
What is HRBITDA?? Any guesses :)

Think of it as EBITDA for HR‚Äîquantifying the measurable value HR brings to the table.

HRBITDA (Human Resources Benefits, Impact, Talent, Development, and Alignment) captures the value HR delivers in a business. It mirrors the concept of EBITDA by stripping away the intangible complexities of HR to focus on real, measurable outcomes like retention, engagement, and leadership development.

HRBITDA is your organization‚Äôs EBITDA for HR‚Äîmeasuring HR‚Äôs true impact on business success
1. Retention ROI = Cost Saved from Reduced Attrition + Lower Hiring Expenses
2. Engagement ROI = Gains from Improved ESAT and Productivity
3. Leadership ROI = Succession Readiness + Leadership Retention Metrics
4. Recruitment Efficiency = Time-to-Hire Savings + Quality-of-Hire Benefits


How to track key metrics for your HRBITDA?

‚Ä¢ Retention Health = % of Key Talent Retained
‚Ä¢ Engagement Health = ESAT Scores / Attrition Rates
‚Ä¢ Talent Pipeline Readiness = Promotions from Within / Total Leadership Hires
‚Ä¢ Diversity Impact = Representation in Decision-Making Roles

How to Build your value?

1. Start-Employee Productivity Improvements
2. Add- Leadership Development ROI (Succession Planning, Retention)
3. Add- D&I Wins (Innovation & Inclusion Gains)
4. Add- Recruitment Efficiencies (Cost and Time Savings)
5. Add- Well-Being ROI (Improved mental health + Reduced Burnout + Increased Productivity)

Now let‚Äôs start from Impact

Reverse-engineer HRBITDA from organizational success
1. Begin- Business Performance Metrics (Revenue/Employee)
2. Subtract- Costs from Attrition and Misalignments
3. Add Back- Gains from Upskilling, Cultural Alignment, and Retention
4. Result - HRBITDA

Why I believe it works?

‚Ä¢ Translates HR‚Äôs value into measurable business outcomes.
‚Ä¢ Mirrors EBITDA to resonate with leadership and financial stakeholders.
‚Ä¢ Simplifies HR‚Äôs impact into clear, actionable metrics.
‚Ä¢ Aligns people initiatives with organizational goals.

Strategic HR Highlights as per my experience
‚Ä¢ Retention ROI- Saved ‚ÇπXX lakhs by reducing attrition through personalized IDPs.
‚Ä¢ Engagement ROI- Boosted ESAT by 15%, driving 10% higher team productivity.
‚Ä¢ Leadership Impact- Increased succession readiness by 40%, ensuring continuity.
‚Ä¢ Recruitment Efficiency- Reduced time-to-hire by 50%, saving ‚ÇπXX lakhs annually.
‚Ä¢ D&I ROI- Achieved 5% growth in women in leadership, driving innovation.

Do you think this remotely makes sense?? OR I am just being silly 

HRBITDA in practice?

‚Ä¢ Check Metrics-Monitor retention, productivity, and engagement regularly.
‚Ä¢ Normalize Data- Benchmark against industry standards.
‚Ä¢ Report Impact-Present HRBITDA as a strategic enabler of growth and profitability.
‚Ä¢ Tie to Business-Show how HR delivers measurable ROI.

Thoughts leaders???

comments.commentText:
Very informative and nicely compiled.
Can you share bench mark for a few industries.

Satheesh SESHADRI 

‚ÄúThank you for the kind words! Benchmarks can vary widely based on industry, region, and company size, but here are some general trends
1. Retention RatesIndustries with high turnover like retail and hospitality often aim for steady improvement, while manufacturing and healthcare tend to focus on retaining specialized talent.
2. Engagement- High performing organizations across sectors prioritize engagement, with industries like healthcare and tech often scoring higher due to structured initiatives, while retail and hospitality may face challenges with frontline roles.
3. Recruitment Efficiency- The time-to-hire varies significantly‚Äîindustries like retail and hospitality often have shorter cycles for frontline roles, whereas specialized roles in manufacturing or healthcare may take longer.
4. Diversity in Leadership Representation efforts are gaining traction across industries, with some sectors, like IT,ITes ,healthcare, leading the way, while others, like manufacturing, are making slower progress.

posts.content:
Starbucks has 16,000 corporate employees. That surprised me. It‚Äôs a coffee place!! 

10,000 current in the US and 6,000 global. I predict at least 10% trimming here. No surprise‚Ä¶but sad for those who will get impacted.

Dust off your resume and find your LinkedIn password! Financially, mentally, and physically prepare for a 9-12 month job search.
